activity.reader:
Tips on Driving Abroad It can be difficult to drive in another country. Driving rules and laws differ from country to country. So do road signs. Also, people in different countries drive on opposite sides of the road! Here are some tips on driving abroad. First, obtain an International Driving Permit (IDP). Most countries accept this permit. It’s easy to get an IDP. Just enter “International Driving Permit” in any Internet search engine and you will get the information you need. Once you have the IDP, carry your own driver’s license with you any time you drive outside your own country. If possible, get a copy of the foreign country’s rules before you begin driving in that country. An excellent source of information is a car rental company in the foreign country. Be aware:
  1. Some countries have a minimum and maximum driving age.
  2. Some countries have penalties for drivers and / or passengers who don’t wear a seat belt. Always "buckle up."
  3. Many countries require you to honk your horn before going around a sharp corner or to flash your lights before passing.
  4. If the drivers in the country you are visiting drive on the opposite side of the road from your own country, it may be a good idea to practice driving in a quiet area before attempting to drive in heavy traffic.
Finally, a word about road signs: In general, the color red on an international road sign signals negative information, such as a warning or prohibition, whereas blue is positive. Simply put, blue says do, red says don't.

pair.question: It’s difficult to get an IDP to drive in another country.
Driving rules are usually the same from country to country.
You can get information you need about IDPs on the Internet.
Once you have an IDP, it’s not advisable to carry your own home-country driver’s license.
You can usually get driving rules from a car rental company in the country you are visiting.
Some countries don’t permit people to drive if they are too old or too young.
It’s never necessary to wear a seat belt outside of your own country.
Some countries require that drivers honk their horn or flash their lights in some driving situations.
In many countries the color of a road sign can help indicate its meaning.
